results.title: Day the world ended
results.creator_credit: Roger Corman and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: B-grade science-fiction from Roger Corman, set in a post-nuclear holocaust world. Just a few survivors are holed up at a ranch (protected from the nuclear fallout by a mountain range) where nerves are frayed and romantic rivalry erupts. These issues are swept aside however when a radioactive mutant creature terrorises the group. Accomplished low budget thriller (reputedly shoot in 9 days) was one of the first to present the horrors of a post-nuclear wasteland — a lawless place, lurking with unpredictable threats. Cast includes: Richard Denning, Lori Nelson, and Jonathan Haze.

results.title: Voodoo woman
results.creator_credit: Edward Cahn, Alex Gordon and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: A mad scientist, residing deep in the jungle, uses the natives’ voodoo for his experiments to create an indestructible monster. It all goes horribly wrong when he creates a hideous-looking female monstrosity who will not yield to his command. Trading on the themes of mercenary greed and manipulative behaviour, Edward L. Cahn presents an intriguing mix of morally dubious characters whose avarice see them meeting suitably sticky ends.

results.title: The Brain eaters
results.creator_credit: Bruno VeSota, Edwin Nelson and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: Crawling, slimy things terror-bent on destroying the world! So runs the tagline for “The Brain eaters”, classic B-grade science fiction about a mysterious alien structure found jutting out of the earth, in small-town USA. After some studious investigating, a senator and a doctor discover that aliens have infiltrated and are controlling the townsfolk. The terror of a mind-controlling alien threat and subsequent loss of governmental power operates as an analogy for the fear of Communist invasion and the accusations of brainwashing that were likened to the “Red threat”.

results.title: Machine Gun Kelly
results.creator_credit: Roger Corman and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: Loosely based on a real-life story, this 1930s depression-era gangster flick stars Charles Bronson in the titular role, as a sadistic killer. A bank robber leading a motley band, Kelly is goaded into more elaborate crime by his ambitious wife who craves media attention and basks in her husband’s notoriety. Alas, Kelly decides to hold the daughter of a wealthy industrialist for ransom. Things go badly when a fractious gang member seeks revenge on his leader. Despite its B-movie credentials, “Machine Gun Kelly” impresses as a claustrophobic crime drama, marking Corman’s move into big-league movie making.

results.title: Score
results.brief_description: Soft-pornography/erotica from director Radley Metzger resplendent with witty dialogue, telephone repairman and funky music. Older married couple Elvira and Jack like to ‘swing’ and indulge frequently in sex parties with strangers or other couples. Betsy and Eddy are younger, naive newlyweds that become the latest object of desire for Elvira and Jack and the game is on to see who will win their conquest first. Eventually, Elvira and Betsy then Jack and Eddy form up to get high and get busy. A fantasy romp that includes dressing-up, drugs and mirrors. Cast includes Claire Wilbur, Calvin Culver, Lynn Lowry, Gerald Grant, Carl Parker.

results.title: Camille 2000
results.creator_credit: Radley Metzger, Audubon Films and Spear Productions
results.brief_description: The swinging sixties are reflected in this free-love erotica romance produced and directed by Radley Metzger. Portrayed via highly stylised costume and set design, the hedonistic lifestyle indulged by Marguerite (Daniele Gaubert) and her friends is in the realm of fantasy. How the very wealthy (or proteges of the wealthy such as Marguerite) spend their time - with wild parties, drugs and alcohol fuelling their passions. The swarthy Armand (Nino Castenuovo) arrives in Rome and instantly falls for Marguerite, upsetting the ‘live for now’ approach she has to love. They begin an affair that sees them run away to live on a yacht until Armand’s father intervenes trying to save his son’s money and reputation. Marguerite returns to her old ways and ends up relying more on drugs to get her through the pain of loosing her true love. They see each other again at a kinky ‘prison’ themed sex party and Camille ends up in hospital where the lovers are able to re-unite. The ‘2000’ of the title not a reference to a year but to the number of lovers Armand would have to have before he could forget Marguerite! Based on the novel “The Lady of the Camilias” by Alexandre Dumas. Shot in Rome with music by Piero Piccioni. Cast includes Elenora Rossi, Robert Bisacco.

results.title: The Lickerish quartet
results.brief_description: This erotic fantasy film is set in an ancient Italian castle where a man and woman live with her adult son. Opening with the family viewing a pornographic movie and commenting on it, the trio then venture out to the local carnival where they meet the star of the movie now working as a motorcycle stuntwoman. They invite the woman back to the house to have a ‘party’ and watch the film together. Bizarrely she is no longer in the film and has been replaced. One by one the mysterious blonde seduces each of the family members resulting a sexual awakening for all of them, until in the end, physical reality is lost to them and they too become part of movie for others to watch. Highly stylised sets, costumes and funky music add to the swinging sixties feel of this Radley Metzger fantasy romp. Based on the story “Hide and Seek” by Michael De Forrest and Radley Metzger. Cast includes Silvana Venturelli, Frank Wolff, Erika Remberg, Paolo Turco.

results.title: The House that dripped blood
results.creator_credit: Peter Duffell, Max J Rosenberg, Milton Subotsky, Amicus Productions and Cinerama
results.brief_description: Four short stories are linked by a police investigation into the dire circumstances in which occupants of a haunted house perish. A mystery writer inhabits the house in order to finish his latest novel, but is overtaken by the idea that his fictionalised killer really exists. In the second episode, a retired businessman becomes obsessed with a waxwork figure of a beautiful woman. Thirdly, a single father to a young girl, who keeps her mysteriously separated from society, falls victim to witchcraft. In the final episode a horror-film actor, seeking authenticity in his work, is given the cloak of a real vampire. These stories are wonderfully creepy and rely not so much on bloodshed, as on supernatural thrills and gruesome trajectories.

results.title: The Beast must die
results.creator_credit: Paul Annett, Max J Rosenberg, Milton Subotsky and Amicus Productions
results.brief_description: A wealthy and ambitious hunter gathers several guests to his expansive country estate with the intention of revealing that one is a werewolf. Initially baffled by their host’s objective, the visitors soon become terrified that one among them may be a killer beast. Resembling an Agatha Christie mystery, this is a promising set-up, but offers little in the way of clues or intrigue, despite the invitation for audience participation to deduce the killer. The film features Christopher Lee as a lycanthrope expert, and there are 1970s blaxploitation overtones with Calvin Lockhart in the lead role. Also known as “Black werewolf”.

results.title: And now the screaming starts!
results.creator_credit: Roy Baker, Max J Rosenberg, Milton Subotsky and Amicus Productions
results.brief_description: In this horror film, set in a haunted house in the late 18th century, Stephanie Beacham plays a young bride who is raped on her wedding night by a ghost who takes the form of a disembodied hand. When she tries to uncover the malevolant, dark secrets of her husband’s ancestry she is thwarted at every turn, and those who try to help her end up dead. Utterly terrorised, her mental health begins to fail and a psychic doctor (Peter Cushing) is employed to cure her. Despite the dated special effects, this British thriller still has vintage appeal, drawing on the themes of demonic possession and a family curse. Also known as “Fengriffen” and “Bride of Fengriffen”. Adapted from the novel by David Case.
